note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
Located in Escambia County, Pensacola was founded as early as the 1670s and serves as the county seat. (Britannica; Wikipedia)

Located in Adams County, Natchez was founded in 1716 under the name Fort Rosalie and was renamed Natchez in 1730. It became part of the newly created Adams County on April 1, 1799. It served as the capital of Mississippi Territory from 1798 until 1802, when it was replaced by Washington. It was reinstated as the capital from 1817 until 1820, when the capital was again replaced by Washington (which was later replaced by the current capital Jackson in 1822). Natchez serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Mississippi Encyclopedia)
The Colony of Georgia was established April 24, 1732. Admitted as the 4th state, Georgia achieved statehood January 2, 1788. (Britannica; Wikipedia)
Located in central Mississippi, Madison County was established on January 29, 1828. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

Currently an independent city, Richmond was founded in 1737 in what was Henrico County at the time of founding and was incorporated on 1742. It became the state capital of Virginia in 1779. During the American Civil War, Richmond also served as capital of the Confederacy. On July 9, 1902, Richmond became an independent city. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Montgomery County, Montgomery was founded in 1819 and serves as the county seat and state capital. (Encyclopedia of Alabama)

gloss.p: When the Civil War began in the spring of 1861, both Union and Confederate authorities soon saw their armies grow to hundreds of thousands of soldiers, far beyond available military supplies. Confederate forces captured several federal arsenals in the South during the secession crisis, but found themselves with only 175,000 shoulder arms, of which 140,000 were older smoothbore muskets. State governors tried to boost the number of weapons in service by calling for private citizens to donate firearms, but such effort could not provide the quantity or quality of weapons necessary for the coming conflict. The Union, too, found itself insufficiently supplied with weapons. However, northern manufacturing capabilities allowed the federal government to rapidly increase the number, and variety, of weapons for Union troops. A small number of Confederate factories managed to produce some firearms for the military, but the Confederacy heavily relied upon foreign imports smuggled through the Union blockade (receiving as many as 340,000 European small arms) and tens of thousands of weapons captured from Union prisoners or supply depots.

The problem also existed for other types of military equipment. The Confederacy had a shortage of cannons. Domestic production eventually provided a small supplement of artillery pieces, but as many as two-thirds of Confederate cannons were captured Union guns. Similarly, the Confederate government struggled to provide horses to its cavalry units. The national government in Washington, D.C., had more authority—and funding—to purchase and provide resources, such as horses, to federalized troops. The Confederate government in Richmond did not have a similar level of authority or budget. State governments were more influential in the production and transfer of resources within their respective state boundaries and were hesitant, or even resistant, to transfer supplies to the Confederate government for military activities away from their states. This problem grew as the war progressed, because Union armies marched deeper into the South, prompting state governments to be even more interested in home defense than the military situation in other parts of the Confederacy. (National Park Service; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Quitman Light Artillery (Confederate) was organized as an independent battery in September 1860 in Hinds County, Mississippi under the command of Capt. J. Frank Kerr and served in the Western Theater under Chalmer's Brigade. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 35; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 875)

Categories:

gloss.p: The Quitman Light Artillery (Confederate) or Captain J. Frank Kerr's Company, was organized as an independent battery on April 11, 1861 in Adams County, Mississippi under the command of Capt. William S. Lovell and served in the Western Theater. It was reorganized as Capt. English's Company, Light Artillery in June 1862 under the command of Capt. Richard T. English. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 35; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 865, 870)

gloss.p: The Vicksburg Light Artillery (Confederate) was organized as an independent artillery battery on February 9, 1861 in Warren County, Mississippi under the command of Francis S. Tull and served in the Western Theater. It was later commanded by Capt. William R. Spears. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 35; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 880)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi. Infantry Regiment, 10th (1861-1862)
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The 10th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on April 17, 1861 in Hinds County, Mississippi under the command of Col. Seaborne M. Phillips and served in the Western Theater under Chalmers' Brigade. It was later commanded by Cols. Robert A. Smith, James Ronald Chalmers, James Barr, Jr., and James M. Walker. It was reorganized in 1862. It was later consolidated with the 7th, 9th, 41st, and 44th Mississippi Infantry Regiments and the 9th Battalion, Mississippi Infantry to form the 9th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry on April 9, 1865. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 18; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 595-605; National Park Service-Battle Units)

gloss.p: Commonly known as the Madison Rifles, Company I of the 10th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (1861-1862) (Confederate) was organized on January 31, 1861 in Madison County, Mississippi under the command of Capt. Joseph R. Davis and served in the Western Theater. It was later commanded by Capt. George R. Fearn. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 18; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 598)

gloss.p: The 9th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized in March 1861 in Alcorn County, Mississippi under the command of Col. James Ronald Chalmers and served in the Western Theater. The unit was reorganized in 1862 under the command of Col. Thomas W. White and served under Chalmers', Tucker's, Anderson's, and Sharp's Brigades. It was consolidated into the 9th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry on April 9, 1865 under the command of Col. William C. Richards. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 17; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 582-592; National Park Service-Battle Units)

Jackson Miss. Sept. 16th.. 1861.

To His Excellency,
John J. Pettus
Gov. Miss.
Sir,—

In obedience to instructions contained in your Commission, bearing date the 26th. Aug. 1861, the undesigned, your Agent, proceeded to Pensacola, and upon exam=ination, and inquiry, obtained the following information relative to strength and condition of our Troops in service at that place.—The 9th Regt. numbers, non-commissioned Officers and privates—818
" 10 Do [gap] " [gap] " 723

Quitman Light Artillery, Natchez, Capt. Lovell
attached to Georgia Regiment [gap] 63
Quitman Light Artillery, Jackson, Capt. Kerr [gap] 63
Vicksburg Light Artillery [gap] Capt. Edwards 75 [gap] 201

A thorough knowledge of the condition and wants of our Troops, can be had, by reference to the accompanying Echibits, A. B. C. & D., "Madison Rifles," Capt Fearn, excepted, they having been amply provided for by the county of Madison, membering 95 men.

He further reports, that upon examination he found 49 "Miss. Rifles" and accountments complete, 40 "Maynard Rifles" all of which have been shipped to your Excellency, and from advice received, will be forthcoming in a few days.
He was also advised of the transfer 600 or 100 muskets from that place to Richmond Va. via Montgomery, no account of
which has heretofore been rendered by your Excellency.
He further reports, that he visited all the Encampments of Troops, and found them in good health with some few except-ions, and they well provided for in the Hospital.
And further, that he procured transportation for and safely delivered, all the articles enlisted to his care, and herewith renders an account of the expenses attend-ing the same.
R. M. Hobson, agent.

1861 [gap] To the State of Mississippi—Dr.
Aug. 26th. For Cash recieved [gap] $80.00
Cr.

By incidental expenses [gap] $71.00
" Cash to balance [gap] 8.90 [gap] 80.00

Respectfully submitted.
R. M. Hobson
